article:
Your friends might be in Australia or maybe just down the road , but they are all just a few clicks  away. Life has   _  for
millions of teenagers across the world who now make friends online.  _  you use chat rooms, QQ, MSN or ICQ, you are  _  of
a virtual community .
"I rarely talk with my parents or grandparents,    _  I talk a lot with my old friends
on QQ," said Fox's Shadow, the online nickname used by a Senior 2 girl in China. "Eighty per cent of my classmates use QQ    _  school."
QQ is the biggest messaging    _  in China. A record 4 million people used it on
Saturday nights in October,  _  to Tencent, the company which
developed QQ.
And Fox's Shadow might well have been one of them. "I log in   on Friday nights, and Saturdays or Sundays when I feel   _  . I usually  _  about 10 hours chatting online every
week,"she said. "But I rarely talk with  _  , especially
boys or men."
Even though she likes chatting, she is careful about making    _  with strangers online.
"You don't know  _  you're talking to. You should  _  be careful about who you trust online."
Many people would like to meet offline when they feel they have got to   _  someone 
very well. Fox's Shadow once met one of her online friends face to face. It was
a girl who was a comic fan like  herself  and they went to a comic
show together.
However, not all teenagers have been so   _  . At the beginning of this year, a 17-year-old girl was
killed after meeting a friend she had found on QQ. The criminals weren't  _  until last month.
A 16-year-old Beijing boy, known online as Bart Simon, dislikes QQ users. "I used to chat on QQ, but I found that most people were talking   _  ," he said. Now he
chats online in English, using MSN. But he spends little time chatting as he
sees it as a  _  of time and money. "If you are really  _  to it, sometimes you just can't cocentrate in class," he said.
